sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change and the standard entropy change for the reaction: 

2HCl(g) + Mg(s) → MgCl2(s) + H2(g) 

Given the following standard enthalpy of formation values: 

- HCl(g) = -92.31 kJ/mol 
- MgCl2(s) = -641.8 kJ/mol 
- H2(g) = 0 kJ/mol 
- Mg(s) = 0 kJ/mol 

Also given the following standard molar entropy values:
- HCl(g) = 186.9 J/Kmol 
- MgCl2(s) = 138.53 J/Kmol 
- H2(g) = 130.7 J/Kmol 
- Mg(s) = 32.85 J/Kmol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ [ΔHf°(products)] - Σ [ΔHf°(reactants)]

ΔH° = [(-641.8 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)] - [2(-92.31 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)]
ΔH° = (-641.8 kJ/mol) - (-184.62 kJ/mol)
ΔH° = -457.18 kJ/mol

To calculate the standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔS° = Σ [S°(products)] - Σ [S°(reactants)]

ΔS° = [(138.53 J/Kmol) + (130.7 J/Kmol)] - [2(186.9 J/Kmol) + (32.85 J/Kmol)]
ΔS° = (269.23 J/Kmol) - (373.8 J/Kmol + 32.85 J/Kmol)
ΔS° = 269.23 J/Kmol - 406.65 J/Kmol
ΔS° = -137.42 J/Kmol

So, the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction is -457.18 kJ/mol, and the standard entropy change (ΔS°) is -137.42 J/Kmol.
